title: 107_hr970
content: SECTION 1. SAFE AND DRUG-FREE SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES. Part A of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years to carry out subpart 2. Subparts 2 and 3 are redesignated as 3 and 4, and sections 4131 through 4134 are redesignated as sections 4141 through 4144. Section 4121 is also redesignated as section 4131. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allocate funds for subpart 2. Sections are redesignated, with section 4121 becoming section 4131 and section 4123 becoming section 4132. Additionally, new sections are inserted after subpart 1. "SEC. 4121. COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS." The Secretary is authorized to provide grants to States for implementing prevention programs meeting high scientific standards. States must submit a plan detailing grant selection criteria, funding only well-defined, proven-effective prevention programs, and disseminating research-based materials. The Secretary will provide technical assistance to help local educational agencies implement proven-effective prevention programs. The State educational agency will evaluate program implementation, measure results in preventing various behaviors, ensure local programs meet requirements, and ensure funds supplement other available resources. The subpart will supplement, not supplant, other funds available for the described purposes, and may include additional criteria as required by the Secretary. SEC. 4122. RESERVATIONS AND ALLOCATIONS. The Secretary reserves and allocates funds among States for implementing programs under this subpart. If a State does not develop a plan meeting requirements, funds are reallocated to other States. SEC. 4123. DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. Each State educational agency receiving funds under this subpart must provide competitive grants to local educational agencies based on demonstrated need. Grants should support startup costs for a prevention plan meeting requirements and ensure equitable distribution. The State educational agency must provide competitive grants to local educational agencies based on demonstrated need to support startup costs for a prevention plan meeting requirements and ensure equitable distribution of awards to different geographic regions within the State. The agency may use up to 5 percent of funds for administrative, evaluation, and technical assistance expenses. "SEC. 4124. LOCAL AWARDS for competitive grants to local educational agencies based on demonstrated need for prevention plans." To be eligible for a subgrant, a local educational agency must submit an application and a plan demonstrating how it will meet program requirements. The grant funds must be used for implementing prevention programs based on reliable research to address various issues and improve student performance. The subgrant program aims to address problem behaviors, improve academic performance, and enhance the mental, emotional, social, and physical health of children and adolescents. It includes developmentally appropriate activities, interventions, and skills improvement, with active engagement of participants and involvement of parents, educators, and community members in planning and implementation. Staff professional development and training are also emphasized. The subgrant program focuses on improving academic performance and addressing problem behaviors in children and adolescents through developmentally appropriate activities. It emphasizes the active engagement of participants, involvement of parents, educators, and community members in planning and implementation, staff professional development, measurable outcome goals, external technical support, and coordination of resources.
